R9STWFQahTrUuAOblXtKEw.text: Despite living minutes away from this place, I hadn't seen it until I was perusing Yelp earlier today. The actual exterior is rather unassuming, and leads down into the basement where the main room is. I went with my boyfriend, who is decently picky about quality food, and we both thought the food was very tasty.We split a fried squid appetizer, duck leg and piglet belly "flesh" mains with two buns each, and a black sesame crème brûlée. Although it was quite pricey, I have to say it was worth it. The fry on the squid was awesome - completely dry and not greasy at all, with a good pepper kick. The server mentioned that he thought the piglet belly was the best dish, and he wasn't wrong: deliciously rendered meat, crispy skin and spicy mustard sauce to go with it. The duck leg was also tender and my boyfriend preferred that one, but it was served lukewarm. The crème brûlée was my favorite though - warm cream, cold ice cream and crispy corn flakes. That dish was a home run.I can't give it five stars because some of the mains came 10-15 minutes and I can't see how they were cooked to order in that time... so some of it wasn't piping hot and fresh. I also wasn't a huge fan of the long communal table for all of the two-tops; it was fairly wide and difficult to talk across the table when there are people right next to you. The ambience was dark and a bit loud but in a good way, as long as you expect that. Service was fine, not bad but nothing to write home about.TL;DR Very good food, decent ambience/service, but rather £££.

photos.caption: Photo of Flesh & Buns - London, United Kingdom. Crispy fried squid!
Photo of Flesh & Buns - London, United Kingdom. Black sesame creme brulee with cherry sorbet and cornflakes... yum.

IdKDhHHHZQTdB66rAExszQ.text: (This review is for Flesh & Buns Fitzrovia, but I can't find them on Yelp)First, any restaurant that has a "press button for pisco sour" (or any alcohol, for that matter, wins!)Korean fried chicken wings are fabulous- an order of 5 is plenty (I should have ordered the buns to eat with these!)I got rabbit katsu (even though I don't like rabbit- dark meat) but the waitress said it was delicious since it was deep fried and the katsu was amazing - light and crispy! The side cabbage slaw was great. Ah, and the buns (2 for £2) are really perfect:)

ZsnbPAGKnqf5b0jsTz90WA.text: This restaurant in one word: over-priced.We started with the grilled scallops. For two scallops the price was outrageous. Do not get.As for the buns, it's ridiculous this restaurant would consider selling them separately. We had the duck and crispy pork. Would recommend the pork over the duck. Also if you run out of buns, wrap the meat in the lettuce they give you for a lighter option.As for drinks they were fine. We had the lychee martini and I forget the name of the other.Overall, all this food can be found in Chinatown for much much less.

hIAEi9eWJoyxdAMM1ODb2g.text: Although the recommended "two buns per person" might seem quite small, I thought it turned out to be just the right amount. For our flesh dishes, my friend and I ordered the braised ox cheek, crispy piglet belly, and salmon teriyaki. Both of us thought the ox cheek was by far the best one. We ended with the signature s'mores dessert, which is a must-have at Flesh & Buns. You get to roast the marshmallows yourself using a miniature fire pit they bring to the table.For an extra kick, pay the toilets here a visit. You'll see why.

K_OY9ru2hgcPmTn6CzPSyw.text: I love Bone Daddies and Shackfuyu so I was really looking forward to Flesh & Buns. We did the tasting menu, which was more expensive than Shackfuyu yet less filling.The highlights were definitely the meat dishes: Korean fried chicken, duck (flesh), and pork (flesh). The s'mores at the end were a nice touch too.The sushi, chips and dips, and tuna tartare were a bit of a letdown. Flesh & Buns was good but I'm not sure I'll be returning, especially when Shackfuyu is only a stone's throw away.

Y9ssk5vJJ5n9IER-yGAtJw.text: First of all, the service - and I mean from the minute I got to the reception/hostess station - was superb. I arrived alone and told him I'd be dining alone. Immediately I was asked, so politely, if I could wait just a minute. Of course, I could. Within 4 minutes, I was gently gathered and walked to the back end/service area of the bar. The host immediately went to the lead bartender and, without any dramatic attention, seemed to ask him to take special care of me. I saw a deferential but cheery nod and a moment later I was being poured a glass of wine (I had been asked on the way what I'd like to drink).  The place was jam packed. Wall to wall, and seemingly standing room only - even at the bar. Yet, within 5 or 6 minutes I was seated at the bar with a clean and well-set place setting. From there, I merely asked the host to choose some light fare for me. He asked my likes/dislikes (the latter of which I have few), and off it went from there. Had the spicy wings and the pork belly with steamed buns. So delicious. So worth the hike from Westminster, and so worth the trip if you're willing to make it - and as raucous as it seemed to be for a Thursday night, it was still worth it for this introvert.

ZIptzRAZN9UjcCGOQ52I4Q.text: I got pulled in fom the street level after reading the board about their lunch special (Express Menu consisting of 2 courses and drink for 19 pounds). It was getting close to my time leaving London, so I felt like celebrating and treating myself a little. Downstairs is very dark and almost club-like with loud rock and roll music. It is softened with industrial/rustic decor and warm lighting. The place serves japanese cuisine, in case you forgotten by now, but it doesn't really matter. If you are a single person you will likely be seated on a long communal table. I was approched quickly by a good looking and friendly server and placed my order for aspargus salmon sushi roll, crispy duck leg and a glass of white wine. Salmon roll was very skimpy and didn't impress me with flavor, but the crispy duck was outstanding! The skin was crispy and meat moist and full of flavor. You can put shredded meat inside the wonderful buns that came on the side, together with other small condiments. As far as wine, my pour was a little modest, I must say.Looking around the place was filled with posh and good looking crowd. I would gladly agree to come be here again, perhaps even check out their all you can eat brunch on Sundays (where my favorite duck legs become ordinary and unlimited item- they were so good, I would come back just for this by itself).

photos.caption: Photo of Flesh & Buns - London, United Kingdom. Crispy duck leg! Amazing

D3-s2GCMMt9CchJgpLWGjQ.text: Be aware that this place get crowded very early. We went there for a very late lunch or a very early dinner, around 5:45, and therefore had no trouble to find a space for two. We sat at this long table in the middle and very soon joined by other groupes of people. Personally, I think we were a bit too close to the others but it was quiet enough to hear each other across the table. Service was quick and effective and we waited less than 10mn before starting our dinner. Salon/avocado and king prawn tempura rolls arrived first, soft and well sized (£6/£7). Then the fried squid, looking good, crispy and slightly spicy lemony, loved it (£8,5). Then we shared a delicious set of crispy piglet belly buns, hot and melting in our mouth!  We were told that a set of buns + 3 small dishes would be enough to fill our belly and it was true. Couldn't manage to fit dessert after this full meal! I was looking forward to the passion fruit and chocolate s'mores. We drank our cocktails (frozen yuzu margarita and lychee pomegranate martini £9 each) and went on our way, full and satisfied! We paid about £50 for two, starters, meal, drinks. It's not cheap but it's a nice way to treat yourself once in a while.

Photo of Flesh & Buns - London, United Kingdom. Frozen yuzu margarita and fried squid
Photo of Flesh & Buns - London, United Kingdom. Salmon avocado rolls + king prawn tempura rolls

MAC6fUdazpdshRj0St34Vg.text: I loved this place, though it's still firmly a few tweaks off five stars. My date and I were seated opposite each other about halfway down the long communal high table in the centre. Which would've been fine, except that we were there on a sort of special occasion and the table was slightly too wide across to talk to each other comfortably, made harder by it being deafeningly loud in there. Like that thing that starts with one loud person that subconsciously makes everyone else talk louder to drown them out and there's no way of lowering the volume again? I mean why have such sexy red decor and low lighting, and then make people sit closer to the strangers on either side of them than their dining partner opposite?!What can I say, we resorted to making eyes at each other across the table (and well, basically shouting) whilst enjoying a good feed. I could stick almost anything in those fluffy white buns and enjoy them, so their 'recommended two buns per person' seemed quite an underestimate to me! As far as the 'flesh' goes we had the crispy piglet belly (which was tender, delicious and served with a mustard miso) and the flat iron steak (which just didn't work as it was far too chewy to take a bite of it from a bun). So we ordered half right at least! I loved the way they served our sake of choice too, from a carafe on ice in a mini crate.The romance factor wasn't quite what I'd hoped for then, though the service was great and it's a beautiful place to look at. The brunch offer caught my eye for another visit - but I'll definitely be more specific on where we'd like to be seated next time!

photos.caption: Photo of Flesh & Buns - London, United Kingdom. Mmm pork belly... can you believe they only recommend 2 buns per person?!
Photo of Flesh & Buns - London, United Kingdom. Sake never looked so good :)

jic9afrHVAd_Ckc5mCCbNg.text: Nice service and yummy buns ;) Solo traveling, I paid this place a visit hoping that there would be bar seating for me to read. Lucky me, I had both a bar option and a communal table option! The server was very kind to me and even though he was busy, he took good care of me. I would recommend this as a great lunch-spot while wandering the streets of Covent Garden.

L-VPaPnjiu6IpYBvPkV0TQ.text: You'll hear no complaints from me baby!!!Flesh&buns....not the kind of buns you tone up in the gym with excessive squats *cough* *cough* But the kind that are soft and fluffy and EDIBLE lol... They have quite a few deals going on so defo find out before you order! You could be missing out on a life changing deal ;) I had the crispy duck and buns... Mm mm mmmm was that duck crispy! So yummy!!!!!!! It comes with two buns,salad,pickled beetroot and sauce of some sort.... Deeeeeelish! For me two buns were perfect but if your tummy is used to larger portions then order more buns.... To be fair I should've ordered at least one more because the two I had were filled to the brim!! Nothing sexy about watching me eat those.. Trust me..Moments later I left with smeared lipstick and a rounded stomach.. If that's not an indication of a good time then what is??? *pounds chest*

nvii46vagjNjQ8A7j15IJQ.text: Being from NYC and having amazing buns @ Ippudo and others, we were curious to eat here after the hype. Wow! Love their interpretation of the bun. Started with a delicious Asian version of guacamole and chips (super crispy rice chips). Next into the buns! You order buns as an 'entree' and they ask you 'how many buns do you want to go with this?'  ** Beware they don't tell you each bun is £2 though, I just assumed the entree bun dish comes with these (really should be included in the price of the dish, star lost). Buns arrived sticky and warm in a covered basket on the side, with lettuce and 2 pieces of thinly sliced cucumber would like on the side.The crispyPork belly was good, a bit too fatty and but buttery and super crispy. Steak was simple and good. Ate homemade smores with passion fruit marshmallows for dessert which were The service was excellent, we got in and out of there in an hour, and the food was out of this world amazing! Me and my doughter ate there when we were visiting London and she said it was her favorite restaurant so far here. We ordered the stake buns and the were really rich. The steak was Jucie and mois and excellent. Ate hike our father makes excellent stake and this was better by far.

TkX6ewmT88v0iLjwUP_yuw.text: Buns were just okay to be honest. Prefer a real Chinese place with pork buns.Sashimi, edamame and chips were good. I was surprised that the sushi was pretty good.I ordered two duck buns for my main and the duck was dry and the sauce was tasteless. The buns were hot and nice and squishy, but how can you screw up buns right? I think I should have tried pork or steak. I was somehow expecting it to taste like Peking duck maybe? High hopes.It's a fun environment. Feels like you're stepping into a night club haha. I might come back.

BSTkPXRPpE7-zdqCTt-9vg.text: Don't eat before you get here. The food was bountiful. It was really good too. I would also prepare to drink. The buns were not my favorite part, the small dishes were but that's just me. Really great for the price!!

lnXvbKssSbbFWrOE3CgFhg.text: Go for the express lunch menu. My girlfriend and I went there for brunch and was handed the menu. There were nothing mentioned of the express lunch. Only full price brunch at 39 pounds with a welcome cocktail and free pour prosecco. The amount of food that came was insane! We couldn't finish it all. The crispy duck and bun was our favourite. The service was good as the server came around often. It's a nice treat. But more value with the express menu!

jhojL4tD2UZHx34-s26Tjw.text: Came here for a birthday and had appalling service. Avoid the server with shaved sides and long hair on top. 98duU_tr_j4gCcel2csO3A.text: Having been to Bone Daddies Soho,  Bone Daddies Shackfuyu and now Bone Daddies Flesh n Buns twice,  what is clear to see is that the Bone Daddies group can produce unique and inspired combinations of food that are well presented and boast a variety of textures and flavours. The decorations throughout the restaurants are similarly themed and successful in creating a sense that you are dining somewhere esteemed and exotic.  However other consistent factors apparent in all these Bone Daddies creations is that the seating can be cramped,  the service abysmal,  the drinks diluted  with ice and the prices a bit higher than necessary. Here is the meal I had at this visit of Flesh n Buns: The Sweet Symphony mocktail drink was a beaker of ice interlaced with a few blueberries with minimal volume of sugary drink lining the bottom. The grilled sweet potato with spicy mayo starter was a pleasant surprise - sweet, spicy and tangy with a soft melt-in-the-mouth texture; an ingenious combination. The half young chicken was a sizeable portion of succulent chicken with a dash of pickle on the side. The buns remain a highlight of the meal; as an avid bun lover I can assure you that these buns are great - soft and delicate when warm as well as fragrant and a good size to handle and fill. (Better than the Yum Bun buns. )As a side-note the toilets certainly leave an impression; they are plastered with indecent  manga cartoons of topless girls exhibiting and/or cradling their breasts - such are the most x-rated wall decorations  I've ever seen for sure!   In short,  Flesh n Buns is a place of highs,  lows and the somewhat bizarre;  worth a visit if you love buns and fancy an intriguing dining experience.

Photo of Flesh & Buns - London, United Kingdom. Glorious buns

y37OeWDO-jdtWsUGd967Zg.text: My best friend and I planned a girls day out combining visiting the Vogue exhibition at the National Gallery followed by the "Bottomless Brunch" offer at F&B. I was very much looking forward to this, but wasn't hopeful it truly would be "bottomless"! I was very happy to be proven wrong! Despite a slightly slow start after our welcome cocktail, we asked our waiter if we could move onto the prosecco and after that he made sure our glasses were never empty! The Sunday brunch deal really is amazing value, £39/£46 per person (the more expensive option allows you to choose from more of the menu). You can choose as many small dishes as you like, we went for the £46 option and the choice was vast! My favourites were Korean chicken wings, chicken yakitori, soft shell crab with jalapeno mayo and the AMAZING grilled broccoli with orange miso. Then it's time for the eponymous flesh and buns, we had sirloin steak and crispy duck leg which you stuff into soft pillowy (but VERY filling) bao buns along with salad leaves, pickled accompaniments and bbq or plum sauce. On both occasions I've eaten here we've agreed that the crispy duck works best against the soft texture of the buns, the steak tastes better just eaten alone. All the while the prosecco was being topped up and we were getting steadily more merry! As the piece de resistance, dessert is brought out - a generous platter of their delicious kinako doughnuts, perfectly runny chocolate fondant with matcha ice cream and the infamous S'mores! My friend's face when she saw how we would toast the marshmallows was priceless. We never felt rushed or table-turned at all, the offer states a two hour limit on tables but we did end up staying almost three hours. Brunch is highly recommended.The only reason it is not 5/5 is while I feel the brunch deal is excellent value, it's quite pricey when dining a la carte - e.g. you have to buy the buns seperate to the flesh at £2 per person. I think the first buns should be included in the price of the "flesh". People concerned about the decor in the toilets - this place is not child friendly anyway to be honest, it's dark, loud and rock n roll and to me is not where i'd take kids. I personally think the pictures in the bathrooms are a good talking point and are part of Japanese pop culture! I will definitely be back, but probably just for the Sunday Brunch.

hXUHNeJiYdtQ0K12Yb4OKA.text: Why am I late to know about this place?! - oh I know, because one time when me and my friends walked in, it was quite the wait and left. After eating here though I can definitely see why....I love what they serve.We went for the taster menu, it's the norm when I want to get to really know a place.Friendly staff, our waiter was good to guide us through our taster menu with a few recommendations.The starters were good, I don't eat raw so I didn't eat the raw starters but my sister said it was nice.I loved the buns! - we ordered the duck leg and pork - as recommended and we finished off with s'mores:) happy tummyI'll be taking my colleagues here for sure when they decide to look for something different

ZPITm_oxnoGXiu8TPFYxAA.text: Came here again for dinner. Food was great, special mention for the chicken yakitori, the crispy pig belly and duck leg buns. The let down, the service - slow and with errors. First issue we were given the wrong side dish, the waitress told us we had ordered it, untrue. One person at dinner asked which desserts were gluten free to which the server said to order the sorbet. When the "sorbet" arrived, it came in the form of doughnuts, clearly the wrong order. The server insisted that we ordered the doughtnuts and couldnt accept that she made the mistake. To wrongly accuse us was simply insulting. Despite the good food, shall not be making a return visit anytime soon.
